awd_titl_txt: A Combined Paleo-Proxy and Modeling Study of Abrupt Climate Change in the Tropical Atlantic and Its Relation to Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation Variability
awd_abstract_narration:
Both coupled climate model simulations and instrumental data analyses indicate that variability in the large scale circulation of the Atlantic Ocean (also called the Atlantic meridional overturning circulation, or AMOC) may be tightly coupled to tropical North Atlantic and subsurface temperature variability through both atmospheric and oceanic processes. While a slowdown of the AMOC results in an atmospheric-induced surface cooling in the entire tropical North Atlantic, the subsurface experiences an even larger warming due to rapid reorganizations of ocean circulation patterns. As a result, recent modeling studies and observational data point to the subsurface of the western tropical North Atlantic as the most sensitive Tropical Atlantic region to respond to AMOC variability.

This study, co-led by a paleoceanographer and a climate modeler from Texas A & M University, combines proxy reconstructions of sea surface and subsurface temperature and salinity with climate model simulations to identify and understand teleconnections between ocean circulation, high latitude variability, and tropical Atlantic climate. Specifically, the researchers will use a time slice approach to investigate the evolution of vertical temperature and salinity change in the western Tropical North Atlantic linked directly to atmospheric and ocean circulation changes during three of the most significant events of the last deglaciation (Heinrich Event 1, the Bolling-Allerod, and the Younger Dryas). They will also test the fidelity of model results by generating similar proxy records for the past 60,000 years. Overall they seek to test the hypothesis that cold periods on the high-latitude North Atlantic correspond to intense subsurface warming in the western tropical North Atlantic, suggesting that western tropical North Atlantic subsurface temperature change is a sensitive indicator of AMOC variability. 

This research will improve understanding of the interplay between ocean circulation and climate change, and could potentially improve predictive capability of tropical Atlantic climate variability. Funding supports two graduate students and fosters greater collaboration between two communities of researchers.

por.por_cntn:
Although there is ample proxy evidence suggesting abrupt climate change characterized glacial climate, there is little data supporting a link with Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC). Recently, modeling studies and subsurface temperature reconstructions have suggested that subsurface warming across the tropical North Atlantic can be used to fingerprint a weakened AMOC during the last ice age because a reduction in the strength of the western boundary allows warm salinity maximum water of the subtropical gyre to enter the deep tropics. To determine if AMOC variability was the cause of past abrupt climate change, we generated and published new, high-resolution Mg/Ca temperature records based on a lower-thermocline dwelling planktonic foraminifera from a southern Caribbean sediment core.  Our subsurface temperature record revealed abrupt increases in temperature at the onset of most abrupt cooling events of the last ice age. These data are some of the first high-resolution marine sediment derived evidence for past AMOC and are consistent with high-resolution climate simulations of subsurface temperature response to abrupt AMOC shutdown.

Next, we reconstructed changes in the West African Monsoon (WAM) across the last deglaciation.  The Niger River has the third largest drainage basin in Africa and drains most of the Sahara and Sahel. In this study, we presented new reconstructions of Niger Delta sea surface salinity and Niger River discharge for the last 20,000 years in order to more accurately reconstruct the onset of the WAM system. Based on calculated δ18OSEAWATER and measured Ba/Ca ratios in planktonic foraminifera (both proxies for changes in surface salinity), these new records reflect changes in precipitation across the Niger River Basin and reveal that the WAM system began to intensify several thousand years after the equatorial Monsoon system in Central Africa.  Our results also suggest that wind strength, rather than changes in monsoon moisture, was the primary driver of dust emissions from the Sahara and Sahel across the last deglaciation.  

We then investigated the relationship between our reconstructed changes in the WAM to changes in subsurface temperature in the eastern equatorial Atlantic, thought to be related to AMOC variability.  To identify the mechanism linking AMOC to the WAM, we generated a record of subsurface temperature variability over the last 21 kyr based on Mg/Ca ratios in deep-dwelling planktonic foraminifera from an eastern equatorial Atlantic sediment core, Fan 17.  Our subsurface temperature record shows abrupt warming in the eastern equatorial Atlantic during both the Younger Dryas and Heinrich Event 1 stadials. We also conducted a new high-resolution 1400-year transient coupled ocean-atmosphere model simulation across the Younger Dryas and found a strong negative correlation between AMOC strength and eastern equatorial Atlantic subsurface temperatures caused by changes in ocean circulation. Our combined proxy and modeling results provide the first evidence that an oceanic teleconnection between AMOC strength and subsurface temperature in the eastern equatorial Atlantic impacted the intensity of the WAM on millennial time scales.

Finally, we developed a novel modeling method using an Atmospheric General Circulation Model coupled to a slab ocean model to separate and compare the atmospheric and oceanic contributions to the teleconnection from high to low latitudes during an AMOC shutdown.  The results show that the oceanic and atmospheric contributions have comparable climate response magnitudes, but different spatial characteristics with the atmospheric contribution being more zonally symmetric than the oceanic counterpart. We further found that the equatorward propagation of the high-latitude surface cooling is induced by increasing surface sensible heat flux in northern mid- latititudes and subtropics and surface latent heat flux in northern equatorial region. The oceanic contribution in the North Atlantic is mainly through changes in freshwater forcing induced oceanic circulation. 

This research project also provided funding or partial funding for three PhD students and training of several undergraduate laboratory assistants.  The research brought together climate researchers experienced in working with state-of-the-art climate models with scientists working on the development of paleo-proxy records. Traditionally, these two fields have worked independently trying to understand the mechanisms involved in abrupt climate change. The students and PIs funded by this proposal gained the valuable experience of working on both aspects of this project.  They received training in both modeling and geochemical proxy reconstruction, which we believe is extremely important in breaking the barrier between the two communities of researchers and educating the future generation of climate scientists. Results of this research were also presented at both national and international conferences and resulted in four published research articles and another research article that is being prepared for submission.
